'''Ole Jacob Broch''' (14 January 1818 – 5 February 1889) was a [[Norway|Norwegian]] [[mathematician]], [[physicist]], [[economist]] and [[politician]]. Broch was born in [[Fredrikstad]], the son of war commissary Johan Jørgen Broch (1791–1860) and Jensine Laurentze Bentzen (1790–1877),<ref name=nbl/> and the brother of the orientalist [[Jens Peter Broch]]. He showed a talent for mathematics at an early age, and after studies in Christiania (today's [[Oslo]]), he travelled abroad. Through studies in [[Paris]], [[Berlin]] and [[Königsberg]], he developed an interest also for [[optics]] and [[statistics]].<ref name=nbl/>

After returning to Norway, he worked with his friend and colleague [[Hartvig Nissen]] to found the school [[Hartvig Nissens skole]] in 1843, which were to have an emphasis on natural sciences and modern languages.<ref name=Brissach/> After finishing his doctorate in 1847, he returned to a position at the university that he had resigned to work with Nissen.<ref name=nbl/> He also taught at the [[Norwegian Military Academy|Military Academy]], and in 1847 he founded the [[insurance]] company [[Gjensidige]] (under the name "Christiania almindelige, gjensidige Forsørgelsesanstalt"),<ref name=Brissach/> which was [[Scandinavia]]'s first [[life insurance]] company.<ref name=nbl/>

Broch entered politics as a local politician in Christiania, and in the period 1862–69 he represented the city in [[Storting|parliament]].<ref name=nbl/> In 1869, he was appointed Minister of the Navy in the [[Frederik Stang's Cabinet|first cabinet]] of [[Frederik Stang]]. After serving as a member of the Council of State Division in [[Stockholm]] in 1871–72, he returned as Minister of the Navy briefly in 1872.<ref name=Stang/> He resigned over differences with his colleagues about government ministers' access to the parliament.<ref name=snl/> After this his attention turned to international tasks. In 1879 he became a member, and in 1883 director of, the [[International Bureau of Weights and Measures]] in [[Sèvres]], France.<ref name=nbl/> This work took up much of the remainder of Broch's life, but in 1884 he was recalled to Norway to attempt to form a government. The constitutional crisis which caused the fall of the so-called ''[[Schweigaard's Ministerium|April Ministerium]]'' of [[Christian Homann Schweigaard]], led to the demand for a new prime minister. Broch failed in this attempt, and returned to France, where he died a few years later.<ref name=nbl/>

Broch received several honours for his scientific and political work. He was a member of the [[Royal Norwegian Society of Sciences and Letters]] from 1849, and he received the [[Grand Cross]] of the [[Royal Norwegian Order of St. Olav]] in 1879.<ref name=nbl/> Internationally, he was created grand officer of the French ''[[Légion d'honneur]]'', and Commander Grand Cross of the [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[Order of the Polar Star]].<ref name=nbl/>

The island [[Brochøya]], north of [[Nordaustlandet]], [[Svalbard]], is named after him.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://miljo.npolar.no/placenames/pages/detailn.asp?placeNameID=01650A |title=Brochøya |publisher=[[Norwegian Polar Institute]] |accessdate=3 December 2011}}</ref>
